content:
The UK’s largest music event did not take place this year, but its competitors did not do enough to challenge its supremacy

MUSIC FESTIVALS, once the rap-span">domain of the rap-span">eccentric, rap-span">fanatical and unwashed, are now a multibillion-dollar global industry. eFestivals, a listing website, counts more than 700 taking place this year in Britain alone, rap-span">encompassing urban day-to-night events as well as out-of-town weekenders. In spite of this rap-span">diversity, the unequivocal leader of the pack remains rap-span">Glastonbury, which will celebrate its half-century in 2020.

It is by far the biggest in terms of size: over 85 stages are dotted across 900 rap-span">acres of rap-span">Somerset land, covering most musical rap-span">niches. Between rap-span">punters, performers and volunteers, combined rap-span">footfall reaches around 200,000 people, temporarily rap-span">outranking Middlesbrough and rap-span">Norwich in terms of population size. Few other events in the British cultural calendar rap-span">loom so large, either. Appearances from superstars such as the Rolling Stones, U2 and rap-span">Adele make national news. The announcement of rap-span">Jay-Z’s headline performance in 2008 rap-span">prompted a rap-span">nasty debate about the rap-span">appropriate place for hip-hop (a complaint that looks rap-span">decidedly rap-span">quaint today, with British rappers such as rap-span">Wiley receiving honours from the queen). The following year it was a hero’s welcome received at rap-span">Glastonbury, rather than two homecoming nights in Hyde Park in London, that brought rap-span">Damon Albarn, Blur’s frontman, to tears.

All this makes the years where rap-span">Glastonbury does not take place a rare chance for others to fill the gap (it opts for a break roughly twice per decade, to let the farmland recover, or to reinforce rap-span">infrastructure). This year was one of those—and it showcased the rickety state of the competition, and of the industry at large. At their peak in the 2000s T In The Park, Reading and Leeds, and V Festival, all weekend events, challenged rap-span">Glastonbury’s rap-span">dominance in national broadcast media and weakened its ability to attract rap-span">exclusive performances. All have waned. V and T In The Park relocated and rebranded as the scaled-down RiZE and TRNSMT respectively. Reading and Leeds remains a popular rite of passage for teenage renegades, but was widely rap-span">mocked for its line-up this year, particularly the rap-span">prominence of Kings of rap-span">Leon. When the band earned its first British headline slot at rap-span">Glastonbury in 2008, it was an rap-span">affirmation of their rap-span">impending global stardom. A decade on, times have changed, leaving the rap-span">Tennessee rockers far behind. They are now about as hip as Bon Jovi.

City-based festivals did not fare much better, particularly in London. AEG Live, an events company which controls concerts at the O2 rap-span">Arena and Hyde Park, created problems. A deal signed with Tower Hamlets rap-span">council granted it full rights to Victoria Park in rap-span">Hackney; the company rap-span">ejected local rap-span">mainstays Lovebox and Field Day from the grounds and established a soulless rap-span">facsimile, All Points East, in their place. Resistance from Friends of Brockwell Park, a community body, halted Lovebox’s intended move to Brixton in south London and the event ended up in west London instead. Field Day, which was granted access to Brockwell Park, suffered crowd crushes, meaning that next year it will probably be forced to find a new home for the second summer running.

AEG’s primary competitor in America is Live Nation Entertainment, a rap-span">merger of Live Nation, an entertainment rap-span">conglomerate, and rap-span">Ticketmaster, a leading ticket-selling rap-span">outlet. rap-span">Whereas British festivals were once rap-span">exempt from this corporate tussle, Live Nation Entertainment’s rap-span">acquisition of a majority stake in Festival Republic, a rap-span">promoter, now gives it a rap-span">portfolio of 21 British festivals. Those, too, were messy. Two shambolic daytime events in north London at the end of June were beset by bar shortages and security issues, with an rap-span">estimated 40% of the hired workforce rap-span">absconding to watch the World Cup. In July rap-span">Wireless Festival, rap-span">bedrock of the rap and R’n’B calendar, was criticised for an rap-span">initial offering of just three female performers. The organisers then waited until the day of closing act DJ Khaled’s performance to inform ticketholders that he had cancelled months before.

Festivals are rap-span">inherently rap-span">precarious and so the rap-span">lure of a transnational company with deep pockets to shore up the risk is understandable. But it means that rap-span">originality is being stymied. The rap-span">murmurs of rap-span">disapproval that greeted many of 2018’s musical bills reflect an rap-span">imbalance between consumer demand for rap-span">inventive programming and a rap-span">paucity of ideas supplied from the top. Liam rap-span">Gallagher, an artist whose best days were in the early 1990s, headlined five festivals. Those were all funded by Live Nation.

Highlights of rap-span">Glastonburys past—rejuvenating the career of a washed-up Johnny Cash in 1994, or inviting the rap-span">Orchestra of Syrian Musicians to open rap-span">proceedings in 2016 in the wake of the Brexit referendum—gave festival-goers intriguing rap-span">incentives to part with their money. The diverse programme and extensive media coverage adds a rap-span">patina of rap-span">prestige to those that make the often-long trip to perform at rap-span">Worthy Farm. The millions of pounds in rap-span">charitable rap-span">donations made by the founding Eavis family are in keeping with the original alternative values of festival culture, proving that size does not rap-span">preclude spirit. It is unlikely that the festival market will ever dry up, but this summer highlighted how many in the field are badly stuck in the rap-span">mud.

paperStatistics.title: British festivals disappointed in a summer with no Glastonbury
paperStatistics.desc: The UK’s largest music event did not take place this year, but its competitors did not do enough to challenge its supremacy
